The International Monetary Fund is expected to approve a $2 billion loan for Brazil on Wednesaday and to support President Fernando Collor de Mello's economic program, Government officials and diplomats said.
The loan, which Brazil requested in December, is a vital step toward restoring the country's international financial credibility.

Brazil, Latin America's biggest debtor, also needs I.M.F. money and confidence to shore up a harsh domestic austerity program. The I.M.F. sent jitters through the Brazilian Government earlier this month when it postponed a decision on the loan. But officials say no further delays are expected.

"Everything is proceeding smoothly, according to our information," Planning Secretary Pedro Parente said in a telephone interview today. He said he expected the I.M.F. to approve the loan on Wednesday afternoon.
Local financial markets rose strongly today on expectations that the loan would be approved, with stocks jumping 6.4 percent on foreign buying interest.
